messages.content:
You are an AI assistant specialized in analyzing web projects developed using JavaScript (Node.js) and the Express.js framework. I need to generate an OpenAPI Specification for a web project based on its backend source code. In `routes/userRoutes.js`, I found that `userRoutes` is implemented to process HTTP requests. To determine the full path with the correct prefix and the acceptable HTTP methods, I found the necessary information in other files.

I'll provide you with the contents of all related files, and your task is to determine and output:

- The full HTTP request path for the endpoint, which must begin with a forward slash (/) and have path parameters wrapped in curly braces ({}).
- Whether all HTTP methods are acceptable, this will override the results for other HTTP methods.
- Whether the HEAD method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the POST method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the OPTIONS method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the TRACE method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the GET method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the PUT method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the DELETE method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the PATCH method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.

You also need to provide an explanation of your results.

message.content:
Summary of determined endpoints (based on the provided source files index.js and routes/userRoutes.js):

Endpoints
- /users/signin
  - allMethods: false
  - head: false
  - post: true
  - options: true
  - trace: false
  - get: false
  - put: false
  - delete: false
  - patch: false

- /users/signup
  - allMethods: false
  - head: false
  - post: true
  - options: true
  - trace: false
  - get: false
  - put: false
  - delete: false
  - patch: false

- /users/forgot
  - allMethods: false
  - head: false
  - post: true
  - options: true
  - trace: false
  - get: false
  - put: false
  - delete: false
  - patch: false

- /users/reset
  - allMethods: false
  - head: false
  - post: true
  - options: true
  - trace: false
  - get: false
  - put: false
  - delete: false
  - patch: false

Explanation / reasoning
- Router mounting and full paths:
  - index.js contains app.use('/users', userRoutes). That prefixes every route declared in routes/userRoutes.js with /users. (index.js lines: app.use('/users', userRoutes))
  - routes/userRoutes.js declares routes: router.post('/signin', ...), router.post('/signup', ...), router.post('/forgot', ...), router.post('/reset', ...). Combining the prefix yields the full paths listed above.

- Which HTTP methods are acceptable:
  - POST: True for each of the four endpoints because each is explicitly registered with router.post(...) in routes/userRoutes.js.
  - GET, PUT, DELETE, PATCH, TRACE: False because there are no router.get, router.put, router.delete, router.patch, or router.trace (no explicit handlers) for these paths in the provided code.
  - HEAD: False — Express automatically provides HEAD responses only when a GET handler exists for the same path. There are no GET handlers for these paths, so no HEAD handler is provided in the code.
  - OPTIONS: Marked True — index.js registers app.use(cors()). The included CORS middleware (cors()) is mounted globally and will process CORS preflight (OPTIONS) requests for these routes. Thus an OPTIONS request will be handled by the middleware (responding to preflight) even though the router does not explicitly define router.options(...) for these paths.
  - allMethods (i.e., "all HTTP methods acceptable"): False — there is no use of router.all(...) or app.all(...) or any wildcard that would make every method accepted; only the specific POST handlers (and middleware-handled OPTIONS) are present.

If you want, I can produce an OpenAPI (OAS3) fragment describing these four endpoints with the methods as determined above.
